root:
<!-- Scroll down to edit the contents of this page. Additional parameters for this template are available at [[Template:Infobox Planet]]. --> Infobox Planet name = Telesto image = [[Image:Telesto cassini closeup.jpg|250px]] caption = Telesto as seen by the [[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]] probe in October 2005 background = #a0ffa0 discoverer = [[Bradford A. Smith|Smith]], [[Harold Reitsema|Reitsema]], [[Stephen M. Larson|Larson]], [[John W. Fountain|Fountain]] discovered = April 8, 1980 semimajor = 294,619 [[Kilometer|km]]<!---Computed using http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/NatSats/NaturalSatellites.html µ value---> eccentricity = 0.000 period = 1.887802 [[Day|d]]ref[http://exp.arc.nasa.gov/downloads/celestia/data/solarsys.ssc NASA Celestia]</ref> inclination = 1.19° (to Saturn's equator) satellite_of = [[Saturn]] dimensions = 29 × 22 × 20 km³ ref name="Porco2006"{{cite journal |author=[[Carolyn C. Porco|Porco, C.C.]] ''et al.'' |title=''Physical Characteristics and Possible Accretionary Origins for Saturn's Small Satellites'' |journal=Bulletin of the American Astronomical Society |year=2006 |volume=37 |pages=768 |url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2006/pdf/2289.pdf}}</ref> mean_radius = 11.8 ± 1.0 kmref name="Porco2006" rotation = [[Synchronous rotation|synchronous]] axial_tilt = zero magnitude = 18.7ref name="magnitude"{{cite web |title=Telesto Statistics |url=http://www.solarviews.com/eng/telesto.htm |accessdate=2007-10-01}}</ref>
'''Telesto''' (pronEngtɨˈlɛstoʊ respelltəLEStoe, or as Greek ''Τελεστώ)'' is a [[natural satellite|moon]] of [[Saturn]]. It was discovered by [[Bradford A. Smith|Smith]], [[Harold Reitsema|Reitsema]], [[Stephen M. Larson|Larson]] and [[John W. Fountain|Fountain]] in 1980 from ground-based observations, and was provisionally designated '''nowrapS/1980 S 13'''.ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/03400/03466.html IAUC 3466: ''Satellites of Saturn''] 1980 April 10 (discovery)</ref> In the following months, several other apparitions were observed: nowrapS/1980 S 24ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/03400/03484.html IAUC 3484: ''Satellites of Saturn''] 1980 June 6,</ref> nowrapS/1980 S 33,ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/03600/03605.html IAUC 3605: ''Satellites of Saturn''] 1981 May 18</ref> and nowrapS/1981 S 1.ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/03500/03593.html IAUC 3593: ''Satellites of Saturn''] 1981 April 16</ref>
In 1983 it was officially named after [[Telesto (mythology)|Telesto]] of [[Greek mythology]].refTransactions of the International Astronomical Union, Vol. XVIIIA, 1982 (confirms Janus, names Epimetheus, Telesto, Calypso) <small>(mentioned in [http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/03800/03872.html IAUC 3872: ''Satellites of Jupiter and Saturn''], 1983 September 30)</small></ref> It is also designated as '''nowrapSaturn XIII''' or '''Tethys B'''.
Telesto is co-orbital with [[Tethys (moon)|Tethys]], residing in Tethys' leading [[Lagrangian point]] (L4). This relationship was first identified by Seidelmann ''et al.''ref name="Seidelmann1981"[[P. Kenneth Seidelmann|Seidelmann, P. K.]]; [[Robert S. Harrington|Harrington, R. S.]]; [[Dan Pascu|Pascu, D.]]; [[William A. Baum|Baum, W. A.]]; [[Douglas G. Currie|Currie, D. G.]]; [[James A. Westphal|Westphal, J. A.]]; and [[G. Edward Danielson|Danielson, G. E.]]; [http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=1981Icar...47..282S&db_key=AST&data_type=HTML&format=&high=45eb6e10af20904 ''Saturn Satellite Observations and Orbits from the 1980 Ring Plane Crossing''], Icarus, Vol. 47 (August 1981), pp. 282–287</ref> The moon [[Calypso (moon)|Calypso]] also resides in the other (trailing) lagrangian point of Tethys, 60 degrees in the other direction from Tethys.
The ''[[Cassini-Huygens Mission|Cassini]]'' probe performed a distant flyby of Telesto on October 11, 2005. The resulting images show that its surface is surprisingly smooth, devoid of small [[impact crater]]s.
